9.2 æ‹“æ‰‘æ’åº

entry.title: Union/Find
entry.content:
7-1 File Transfer

Score: 13
Author: é™ˆè¶Š
Affiliation: æµ™æ±Ÿå¤§å­¦

Description

We have a network of computers and a list of bi-directional connections. Each of these connections allows a file transfer from one computer to another. The question is: Is it possible to send a file from any computer on the network to any other?

Input Specification

Each input file contains one test case. For each test case, the first line contains N (2 â‰¤ N â‰¤ 10^4), the total number of computers in a network. Each computer in the network is then represented by a positive integer between 1 and N. Then in the following lines, the input is given in the format:

  • I c1 c2
    where I stands for inputting a connection between c1 and c2; or

  • C c1 c2
    where C stands for checking if it is possible to transfer files between c1 and c2; or

  • S
    where S stands for stopping this case.

Output Specification

For each C case, print in one line the word "yes" or "no" if it is possible or impossible to transfer files between c1 and c2, respectively. At the end of each case, print in one line "The network is connected." if there is a path between any pair of computers; or "There are k components." where k is the number of connected components in this network.

Sample Input 1

5
C 3 2
I 3 2
C 1 5
I 4 5
I 2 4
C 3 5
S

Sample Output 1

no
no
yes
There are 2 components.

Sample Input 2

5
C 3 2
I 3 2
C 1 5
I 4 5
I 2 4
C 3 5
I 1 3
C 1 5
S

Sample Output 2

no
no
yes
yes
The network is connected.

entry.title: FDSProject3Report
entry.content:
FDS Project3 Report

Chapter 1 Introduction

Railway transportation remains one of the most utilized methods for long-distance travel, offering a balance between speed, cost, and convenience. Efficient pathfinding algorithms are critical in optimizing railway networks, ensuring minimal travel time and enhancing passenger experience. The conventional approach to pathfinding in railway networks typically involves finding the shortest route from the origin to the destination. However, this approach does not account for various real-world scenarios such as network congestion, scheduled maintenance, or the travelerâ€™s preference for a non-shortest path due to reasons like sightseeing.

In light of these considerations, there emerges a need for an algorithm capable of identifying not just the shortest path but also alternative routes that are the next best in terms of travel distance. Such an algorithm expands the operational flexibility of railway networks and accommodates a broader range of traveler preferences.

Chapter2 Algorithm Specification

Overview

The core problem addressed in this report is the computation of the second-shortest path in a directed railway network graph. The approach taken can be segmented into two primary components: the Dijkstra algorithmâ€™s application to identify the shortest path and the identification of cycles to facilitate the discovery of the second-shortest path when the direct approach is insufficient.

Shortest Path Computation

The algorithm begins with a conventional Dijkstraâ€™s algorithm to calculate the shortest path from the start station to the destination. Each nodeâ€™s minimum distance from the start node is stored, along with its predecessor, to reconstruct the path upon completion of the algorithm.

Edge Blocking and Re-evaluation

Subsequently, the algorithm iteratively â€œblocksâ€ sections of this shortest path by temporarily assigning an excessively high weight to the edges in the path and then re-applying the Dijkstra algorithm. This process is intended to reveal alternate routes that are longer than the shortest path but potentially the second-shortest. These paths are evaluated against the existing second-shortest path candidate, with the shortest among them being selected.

Cycle Detection

The algorithm also incorporates a depth-first search (DFS) to identify the smallest cycle originating from each node. The cycleâ€™s length is compared to the second-shortest path candidate, and the shorter of the two is chosen as the solution.

Data Structures

The implementation uses adjacency lists to represent the graph, with vertices and edges encapsulated in structs. A priority queue, realized through a min-heap, is employed for efficient retrieval of the node with the smallest tentative distance during the Dijkstra algorithmâ€™s execution. Additionally, arrays are used to track the shortest path, the existence of cycles, and other intermediate states within the algorithm.

Data structures defined are as follow

Complexity Analysis

The time complexity of Dijkstraâ€™s algorithm is O((M+N)logM), where M is the number of nodes and N is the number of edges. The edge blocking and re-evaluation process add an additional factor, as the Dijkstra algorithm is applied iteratively. Cycle detection through DFS contributes O(N+M) per node for a complete traversal. The overall complexity is dominated by the repeated application of Dijkstraâ€™s algorithm.

Conclusion

The specified algorithm is designed to balance computational efficiency with the need to address the non-trivial problem of second-shortest path discovery in graphs that may contain numerous cycles and varying edge lengths. The following chapters will delve into the implementation details, providing code snippets and explanations of key functions within the algorithm.

Chapter 3 Testing results

Chapter 4 Analysis and Comments

In the analysis above, weve reached the conclusion that the time complexity of Dijkstra algorithm is O((M+N)logM) and FindCycle has the time complexity of O(N+M), itâ€™s highly acceptable because of the application of priority queue(min heap in the code) to optimize the Dijkstra process.

Potential Improvement

Appendix : Source Code

Declaration

I hereby declare that all the work done in this project titled "MAXIMUM SUBMATRIX SUM PROBLEM " is of my independent effort.

entry.title: FDSProject2Report
entry.content:
Chapter 1ï¼šIntroduction

Differentiation is an indispensable part of advanced mathematics, but when the number of variables becomes too large, manual differentiation becomes particularly cumbersome. Consequently, we aim to write a program that automatically differentiates with respect to all the variables contained in an expression and provides the simplified results.

Chapter 2 ï¼šAlgorithm Specification

The data structures and definitions involved in this program are listed as follows.

From Infix To Postfix

Then we need to convert the infix expression that has been read into a postfix expression before transforming it into an expression tree. Actually, it is possible to directly convert from an infix expression to an expression tree, but the aforementioned process is simpler and easier to understand. The key point during the conversion to a postfix expression is how to distinguish between variable names like â€œxâ€ and â€œxyâ€, as well as function names such as â€œlogâ€ and â€œpowâ€.

Converting an infix expression to a postfix expression involves a process where operators are moved after their operands.

  1. Create an Operator Stack: A stack is initialized to keep track of operators and to help with the precedence rules.

  2. Iterate through Characters in the Infix Expression: The function loops through each character of the infix expression.

  3. Handling Operands (Variables and Numbers):

    • If the character is an alphabetic letter, it may be part of a variable or a function like sin, cos, ln, etc.
    • For functions, the code checks for precedence before pushing them onto the stack.
    • If it is a standalone variable, it is directly moved to the postfix array.
    • Numbers are similarly directly moved to the postfix array.

  4. Handling Operators:

    • When an operator is encountered, any operators on the stack with higher or equal precedence are popped from the stack and added to the postfix array.
    • The encountered operator is then pushed onto the stack.

  5. Handling Parentheses:

    • An opening parenthesis ( is pushed onto the stack.
    • If an opening parenthesis is immediately followed by a unary + or -, the code modifies the expression to handle it correctly.
    • A closing parenthesis ) causes the stack to be popped until the corresponding opening parenthesis is encountered. The operators popped off are added to the postfix array.

  6. Handling Functions with Arguments (like log, pow):

    • The code identifies functions with arguments by matching specific function names and then parses their arguments.
    • The arguments themselves are processed by a recursive call to infixToPostfix.
    • After processing the arguments, the function name is treated as an operator and handled accordingly.

  7. Completing the Postfix Array:

    • After the entire infix expression has been read, any remaining operators on the stack are popped and added to the postfix array.

The precedence function (not shown in the code provided) likely determines the precedence of operators. The precedence rules define the order in which operators should be evaluated, typically: () > ^ > */ > +-.

The postfix array holds the resulting postfix expression, and memory allocation is performed as needed for each token added to this array. Memory management is crucial in this process to avoid leaks.

Warningï¼šItâ€˜s so long and I know that you donâ€™t want to read it at all. Please pay attention to some special string like â€œlogâ€â€œexpâ€

Create Expression Tree

Now weâ€™ve got postfix expression and the next step is to create an expression tree from postfix expression.

Creating an expression tree from a postfix expression involves the following steps:

  1. Initialize an Empty Stack: Begin by creating an empty stack that will be used to hold nodes of the expression tree.

  2. Iterate Over Postfix Elements: Process each element in the postfix expression from left to right.

  3. Create Nodes for Operands and Operators:

    • Operands: When you encounter an operand (a number or a variable), create a tree node with no children (since operands are leaves in the expression tree) and push it onto the stack.
    • Operators: When you encounter an operator:
      • For a binary operator (like +, -, *, /, pow, log), pop the top two nodes from the stack. The second node popped is the left child, and the first node popped is the right child of the operator node. Then, push the newly created operator node back onto the stack.
      • For a unary operator (like sin, cos, exp, ln), pop the top node from the stack and make it the right child of the operator node (unary operators usually have only one operand). Then, push the operator node onto the stack.

  4. Handle Special Cases:

    • If there is an operator with different arity (number of operands), special handling is needed to correctly assign children.
    • Additionally, if the stack runs out of elements prematurely or contains extra elements at the end, this might indicate an error in the postfix expression.

  5. Complete the Tree: After processing all elements of the postfix expression, the stack should have only one element left. This single element is the root of the constructed expression tree.

  6. Return the Expression Tree: The final tree represents the hierarchical structure of the postfix expression and can be used to evaluate the expression or to convert it to other forms (like infix or prefix).

Differentiate(The Most Important Part!!!)

Now we get a postfix expression based on which we could differentiate for every variable recursively.

The principles involved are listed as following:

The provided code is a C function designed to compute the derivative of a mathematical expression represented as a binary tree, where each node can be an operand, a variable, or an operator. The purpose of the function is to differentiate the expression with respect to a given variable and return the result as a string.

Here are the key concepts and processes used in the code:

  1. Recursive Traversal:
    The function processes various mathematical operations by recursively traversing the expression tree.

  2. Basic Derivative Rules:

    • The derivative of a variable (e.g., x) is 1.
    • The derivative of a constant or an expression that does not contain the variable is 0.

  3. Sum and Difference Rule:

    • The derivative of f + g is f' + g'.
    • The derivative of f - g is f' - g'.

  4. Product Rule:

    • The derivative of f * g is f' * g + f * g'.

  5. Quotient Rule:

    • The derivative of f / g is (f' * g - f * g') / g^2.

  6. Chain Rule for Composite Functions:

    • The derivatives of functions like sin, cos, tan, ln, exp, pow, etc., are computed using the chain rule.

  7. Power Function Derivative:

    • The derivative of f^g is g * f^(g-1) * f' + ln(f) * g' * f^g.

  8. String Operations:

    • The strcat function is used to append the derivative results to the string result.

  9. Helper Functions:

    • The checkNode function is assumed to check if a node contains the variable.
    • The inorderTraversal function is assumed to perform an in-order traversal of the tree and append the expression to the result string.

  10. Handling Special Functions:

    • The derivatives of special mathematical functions (like log) are calculated using specific rules.

Simplify

Aftering differentiating, we may gets millions of brackets. Itâ€™s so horrible because the purpose of programming is to make human being more relaxed rather than hit them with nauseating expressions.

  1. Recursive Simplification:

    • The function first recursively calls simplify on the left and right child nodes.
    • After simplifying the child nodes, it attempts to simplify the current node.

  2. Handling Addition (+):

    • If either child is â€˜0â€™, it is an additive identity and can be removed (e.g., x + 0 simplifies to x).
    • If both children are â€˜0â€™, the entire expression simplifies to â€˜0â€™.

  3. Handling Subtraction (-):

    • If the left child is â€˜0â€™ and the right child is also â€˜0â€™, the expression simplifies to â€˜0â€™.
    • If there is no left child and the right child is â€˜0â€™, the expression simplifies to an empty string (effectively removing the node).
    • If the left child is â€˜0â€™, the expression simplifies to the negative of the right child (e.g., 0 - x simplifies to -x).
    • If the right child is â€˜0â€™, it can be removed, leaving just the left child.
    • If both children are numeric, their values are subtracted and the result is stored in the current node.

  4. Handling Multiplication (*):

    • If either child is â€˜0â€™, the entire expression simplifies to â€˜0â€™ due to the multiplicative zero property.
    • If both children are â€˜1â€™, it simplifies to â€˜1â€™ due to the multiplicative identity.
    • If one child is â€˜1â€™, it can be removed, leaving the other child.

  5. Handling Division (/):

    • If the left child is â€˜0â€™, the entire expression simplifies to â€˜0â€™.
    • If the right child is â€˜1â€™, it can be removed, leaving just the left child.

  6. Handling Power (^):

    • If the left child is â€˜0â€™, the entire expression simplifies to â€˜0â€™.
    • If the right child is â€˜0â€™, the expression simplifies to â€˜1â€™.
    • If the right child is â€˜1â€™, the expression simplifies to the left child.

  7. Handling Logarithmic (log) and Natural Logarithm (ln) Functions:

    • If the argument of log or ln is â€˜1â€™, the expression simplifies to â€˜0â€™.
    • For log, if the base and the argument are the same, the expression simplifies to â€˜1â€™.

  8. Handling Trigonometric Functions (cos, sin, tan):

    • For cos, if the argument is â€˜0â€™, the expression simplifies to â€˜1â€™.
    • For sin and tan, if the argument is â€˜0â€™, the expression simplifies to â€˜0â€™.

  9. Cleaning Up:

    • After simplification, the current nodeâ€™s children are set to NULL, indicating that they are no longer part of the simplified expression.

  10. String Operations:

  • Uses strcpy and strcat to manipulate the value within the nodes.

  • Uses sprintf to convert the result of numeric computations back to a string.

Get InorderTraversal

In the end, we need to inordertraverse the expression tree to get the result in infix expression.

  1. Base Case:

    • The function returns immediately if the current node is NULL.

  2. Handling Binary Operators (+, -, *, /):

    • For nodes containing binary operators, it adds a left parenthesis before recursively traversing the left subtree.

  3. Handling Functions (log, pow, ln, cos, sin, tan, exp):

    • For nodes representing functions like log and pow, it appends the function name, followed by a left parenthesis.
    • It then recursively calls itself on the left and right children (if applicable), separated by a comma for log and pow.
    • For functions like ln, cos, sin, tan, and exp that take a single argument, it calls itself on the right child only.

  4. Handling Operands (Variables and Numbers):

    • For nodes containing a variable or number, it appends the node value directly to the result string.
    • It then continues the traversal to the right child, if any.

  5. Recursive Traversal:

    • For other nodes, it first recursively traverses the left child, then appends the nodeâ€™s value, and finally traverses the right child.

  6. Closing Parentheses for Binary Operators:

    • After traversing both subtrees of a binary operator, it adds a right parenthesis to complete the expression.

  7. String Concatenation:

    • Uses strcatto append characters to theresult string.

Chapter 3 Testing results

Input: a+b^c*d

Result:

Input: a*10*b+2^a/a

Result:

Input: xx2/xy*xy+aa

Result:

Input: x*ln(y)

Result:

Input: x*ln(x*y)+y*cos(x)+y*sin(2*x)

Result:

Input: log(a,b)/log(c,a)

Result:

Input: pow(3,a)

Result:

Input: cos(x)+sin(y)-tan(a)

Result:

Chapter 4 Analysis and Comments

Itâ€™s F**king so complicated and terrible!!!

Anyway,it is a correct and effective algorithm. However, a major issue is that due to the complexity of the program, I did not pay attention to some details of memory allocation, and directly used fixed arrays, which obviously wastes a lot of space. But it doesnâ€™t really matter when running the program locally. Moreover, the addition of parentheses could be optimized, but I am too tired. Additionally, this program should be presented in an engineering format, but Iâ€™m not very accustomed to using it yet. This program has already met the basic requirements and the bonus requirements.

Appendix : Source Code

Declaration

I hereby declare that all the work done in this project titled "MAXIMUM SUBMATRIX SUM PROBLEM " is of my independent effort.
